.@bcheungz: "Would you describe what you want to do as a gradual hiking?"

Chair Powell: "This is going to be a year in which we move steadily away from the very highly accommodative monetary policy that we'd put in place to deal with the economic effects of the pandemic." More: https://t.co/mP17XQBY8U

"There's nothing in our framework about having inflation run below 2%," Chair Powell says. "What we're trying to do is keep inflation expectations well-anchored at 2%. That's always the ultimate goal." https://t.co/Jb7k9tf4PH https://t.co/gfSEmU3PvL
"Since the December meeting, I would say the inflation situation is about the same but probably slightly worse," Fed Chair Jerome Powell says. https://t.co/Jb7k9tf4PH https://t.co/VtZNyjGwHu

"I would say the committee is of a mind to raise the federal funds rate at the March meeting assuming that conditions are appropriate for doing so," Fed Chair Jerome Powell says. https://t.co/Jb7k9tf4PH https://t.co/jvAHfoCclV

"The balance sheet is much bigger," Chair Powell says. "It has a shorter duration than the last time, and the economy is much stronger and inflation is much higher. So I think that leads you to... be willing to move sooner than we did in the last time and perhaps faster." https://t.co/PQaJZT0Ly8

"I think there's quite a bit of room to raise interest rates without threatening the labor market," Fed Chair Powell says. "This is, by so many measures, a historically tight labor market." https://t.co/Jb7k9tf4PH https://t.co/xn11k5JYxB

"In light of the remarkable progress we've seen in the labor market and inflation that's way above our 2% longer-run goal, the economy no longer needs sustained high levels of monetary policy support," Chair Powell says. "That is why we're phasing out our asset purchases." https://t.co/vQUYrCZlAS

"Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2%," Chair Powell says, and adds: "While the drivers of higher inflation have been predominantly connected to the dislocations caused by the pandemic, price increases have now spread to a broader range of goods and services." https://t.co/LwHEfBS9l3

"While labor force participation has edged up, it remains subdued, in part reflecting the aging of the population and retirements," Chair Powell says. And, "some who'd otherwise be seeking work report they're out of the labor force because of factors related to the pandemic." https://t.co/M9KN0zH2qC
"Our policy has been adapting to the evolving economic environment, and it will continue to do so," Fed Chair Jerome Powell says. https://t.co/Jb7k9tf4PH https://t.co/ieYwM0Y6P6
